item.description:
Balap Kuliner tells about the local and foreign tourists who meet at culinary festivals in the city of Semarang. They have to find the fastest way to the store that sells the food. Not to mention they will face the heat of the weather and the crowded traffic jam in the downtown. Not only that, they also need to wait for the shuttle bus on the right timing to get them home and bring the delicious culinary safely. Balap Kuliner is suitably played for 2-4 players, with age of 10 years old. With the grid movement and card mechanics, this game is easy to play and only take 15-20 minutes for each game.

—description from the publisher

A free print and play game to be played at conventions. Each player or team prints out a copy of the game, then writes a character you might see someone dressed up as next to each constellation. Whenever you see someone with that cosplay, fill in one star for that constellation. Challenge your friends to see who fills in their page first!

Knock Knock is "a fast-paced, competitive game for friends and future enemies." In this card game players compete to be the first to get rid of their hands.
Like other card shedding games, play proceeds as players discard matching the suite or value of the previously discarded card.

However, players with a matching card may "cut in" out of turn skipping other players and moving closer to victory.

Various special cards also add fun and silly elements such a slapping, silence and moose antlers.

item.description:
Roll into the action in this easy to learn and quick to play dice game for 2 or 4 players. Sports Dice: Football includes all the drama of a real game. Go for it on 4th down and reach the end zone to score a touchdown. Then try to stop the opposing team by sacking their quarterback.

The team that starts on offense starts on their own 25-yard line. They have 4 downs to get to the 50-yard line or beyond. Once they reach (or cross) the 50-yard line, they receive a new set of downs and now have 4 tries to get to the opposing team’s end zone.

Both team simultaneously roll all their dice. The symbol that appears the most on each team’s set of dice becomes their play. The team that rolled the most dice with the same symbol wins the roll. Apply the outcome of the winning play by moving the Football Token and/or Down Marker Token accordingly. See the Dice chart for a description of each symbol.

The game ends when one team has scored 21 points or more. That team is victorious!

—description from the publisher

link.value: Dr. Livingstin's Sports Dice: Football Edition

item.description:
Empires: D10 Edition follows from the popular Empires: Core Rules rulebook, but with one BIG exception, a diced wargame mechanic; the first published diced wargame from War of Life Gaming.

Immerse yourself in the living rulebook that brings diversity to the old world; fighting Greek Hoplites with Napoleon’s Hussars, or Praetorian Cavalry with Templar Knights, or Elves with Dwarves.

Defeat you're opponents with tactical prowess and superior skill. Using small to large units of troops, ranging from the ancients to the Napoleonics and from any scale, you hope to weaken the enemy so that they flee, or are wiped out.

Empires is suitable for all war-gamers, beginner or veteran; as the rules can be basic or advanced depending on how many upgrades are taken for each unit; and with over 16 unit types/variances, and more than 50 upgrades/modifiers, no battles will be the same.

As a core rulebook, players are able to take the rules and expand on them, introducing new armies or wargear at their own leisure; to share with others and/or for their own entertainment.

The Empires rulebook is a guideline only. You take control of the game.

—description from the publisher

Konkvest is a chess-type board game specifically made to be played by two players. It is played on a hexagonal board with 142 tiles, as players alternate taking their turns to move their pieces. The tiles are distributed in 13 rows, the middle row has 12 tiles in total and each subsequent row on the higher and the lower level has one tile less, ending with 6 tiles in the final rows. There are additional 28 tiles with specific use defined in the manual.

The game is intended to serve as an official chess in the fantasy world of Atharon. After its conception, the game took on a life of its own and, rather than remaining just a footnote and a mere mention in the world of Atharon, it became a fully-realized project.

Since its intention is to basically be Atharon chess, it's played similarly to the regular game of chess we all know. Players alternate turns moving their pieces across the board in accordance with the rules of movement. The rules of movement are too complicated to be described in text so they are explained in pictorial form in the rulebook.

The main goal is to win the game by beating the opponent by toppling his Queen. Alternative ways include capturing the opponent's base by placing one's Queen on the specific tile the opponent's Queen started off, which is easier said than done. Another alternative way to win the game is to force the opponent's timer to expire.

By standard a Konkvest game is timed using a 10 minute hourglass, which is balanced out at the start of the game so each player has 5 minutes at his disposal. Once set, the hourglass is laid horizontally. The player who makes the first move lifts the hourglass vertically and the time measurement begins. At that moment, the top chamber of the hourglass represents the time available to the second player. Once the second player makes his move, he flips the hourglass upside down so his chamber is at the bottom. Then it's the first player's turn again. The more one player spends on thinking, the less time he will have for future moves and the more time he will provide to his opponent, and vice versa. The player who's time runs out loses the game.

During his turn, a player can do one of the following things:
1.) He can move one of his pieces according to the rules of movement on a different tile. If that piece ends its move within that player's promotional zone and hasn't captured an opponent piece, the player can promote that piece. If that piece ends its move on a tile occupied by an opponent's piece, the player takes that piece and adds it into his reserve pool, effectively capturing it. The only piece that cannot be captured is the Queen, once she's toppled the game is over.
2.) He can pick up one of his pieces from his reserve pool and return it on the board as an active piece, strictly within the territory he currently controls.

At the end of his turn, the player flips the hourglass and then it's his opponent's turn to do the same procedure.

Konkvest is an abstract battle simulation, meaning all of its resources are limited. Players have a limited amount of pieces and a limited amount of movement, they have a limited amount of spots in their reserve pool and they have a limited amount of time to spend on making their move.

"Crime - do not cross" it's an Investigation card game.
Someone has tried to kill the king of England and now you have to find out who it was ... Not alone, but with the help of the most famous detectives in the world.

In a first deck we find 10 detective and some tools. The tools need to increase the value of each detective.

Each player must play with 2 private cards in his hand.
On the Table we find 9 public card and each player must reserved 3 of this in a row, in a coloumn or in diagonal (like tic tac toe).

Only the public cards reserved by a single player can increase the value of their investigation.
Who has the highest value, can investigate and find the clues to solve the case.

A player wins when find all the right clues or if it's the last in game.

Dice Tiles is a tile placement and dice placement game. Once tiles are placed, Dice may be added or removed to maximize points. Whom ever has the most points when the final die is placed is the winner.

Vs System 2PCG is superficially similar to the original Vs. System collectible card game, but is a completely rebuilt game that takes some inspiration from the original. Combat has been streamlined, the turn structure is different, the resource system has been revamped, and the game is no longer collectible, with cards instead being released in a non-random format. A single box contains a full play-set of all cards.

Each player starts with a Main Character, such as Captain America, Iron Man, or Loki and a deck of 60 cards. During the game, you’ll play resources and recruit Supporting Characters like Falcon, Baby Groot, or Nebula. You’ll organize your formation between your Front and Back Rows, you’ll make solo and team attacks against your enemies in order to stun and KO them. You’ll play Plot Twists to enhance your team or hurt your opponent’s. You’ll play locations and activate your team’s super powers. Your Main Character will earn Experience Points and Level Up to dominate the battlefield. Finally, you’ll KO your opponent’s Main Character (or they’ll KO yours).

Each turn, you’ll go through the following four phases in order. Then, the next player takes a turn.
1. Draw Phase - Draw 2 cards from your deck
2. Recovery Phase - Any stunned characters are recovered and then readied.
3. Build Phase - Play a resource or Location. Then using you total resource points recruit new characters form your hand based on their cost.
4. Main Phase - The longest phase consisting of multiple combats as you attack your opponents characters trying to stun and KO them.

The first issue of the Earth 199999 Arc, Vs System 2PCG: The MCU Battles is also the first Giant-Sized Issue of 2018. It not only creates a new Universe for vs System 2PCG is also introduces two new teams. The MCU Heroes and MCU Villains. This 200 card Giant-Sized Issue is perfect step on point for new players as this comes with a full set of cards with images straight from the movies, counters, and a full color rulebook.

-description from publisher

link.value: Vs System 2PCG: The MCU Battles – MCU Heroes
Vs System 2PCG: The MCU Battles – MCU Villains

name.value: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game – Marvel Studios, Phase 1

item.description:
Welcome to Legendary, the Marvel Deck-Building Game! Evil Masterminds like Loki and Red Skull lead a horde of powerful Super Villains, planning dark Schemes to destroy the Marvel Cinematic Universe! Only you can stop them, leading awesome Marvel Super Heroes like Captain America, Iron Man, and Thor!

In this game for 1-5 players, each player starts with their own deck of basic Hero cards. At the start of your turn, you play the top card of the Villain Deck, showing how Villains invade the city, capture Bystanders, and create special events. Then you play Hero cards from your hand to generate Attack, Recruit Points, and special abilities. You attack with your Heroes to defeat Villains. You use Recruit Points to recruit better Heroes to add to your deck.

Whenever your deck runs out of cards, you shuffle your discard pile to make a new deck, including all the new Heroes you recruited. This way your deck gets stronger and stronger over time. Build up enough Power and you can defeat the evil Mastermind! But be careful: if the players don’t defeat the Mastermind quickly enough, then the Mastermind will complete their dark Scheme and win the game for evil!

In Legendary: Marvel Studios Phase 1, the Avengers are back in a new setting with images straight from the Phase 1 movies of the Marvel Cinematic Universe (Iron Man, Incredible Hulk, Iron Man 2, Thor, Captain America: The First Avenger, Avengers). Black Widow, Iron Man, Captain America and more face off against the Villains of the first six movies. Three Masterminds including the all new Iron Monger and his Iron Foes try to complete their evil schemes. This nearly 400 card sets comes with a full color rulebook and an updated playmat.

—description from publisher

item.description: A boardgame covering the Six-Day Arab/Israeli War in June, 1967. Includes a detailed three-front map (covering Sinai, The West Bank, and the Golan Heights). The diplomatic situation leading up to the outbreak of open hostilities on each front is covered with card play, while the warfare itself is covered as a traditional hex-and-counter affair. The game includes a historical scenario, and an alternate history setup where the Arabs are fighting (at least a little less) "against the odds."

link.value: Six Days of War: The Arab-Israeli Conflict, 1967

name.value: Game Box: Family Feud – Marvel Edition

item.description: "Survey says...the card game based on the popular tv show Family Feud. Give the most popular answers to a variety of MARVEL themed survey questions to win.

Everyone is here, and our party is ready to begin! The best part is that our table is filled up with all kinds of presents, but everyone wants the best ones for themselves!

Gift Party is a very easy game to learn and it contains a lot of fun for everyone in the family. It is a game about collecting presents and it is built upon easygoing mechanisms.

The aim of the game is to collect as many gift as possible, but watch out, because not all the gifts the players could collect are worth of keeping them, since everyone has a Gift List and they need to stick to it. Since then, the first action for every player will be to withdraw a card from the deck. This card should have five different gifts represented and, as you already deduced, it is our Gift List.

To acquire different presents from the table, every player should roll the die. When the present is collected, the players could perform different actions with their gifts (open & keep them, exchange them with other players or even steal gifts from another player's reserve). Some gifts will also let you perform extra actions during your turn.

Every player should make an effort to collect the gifts represented in their Gift List, since only the gifts that appeared in this card will push them closer to the victory. They will try to hide which ones are part of their list and, at the same time, they need to ditch all the gifts that there are worthless, according to their list.

Once there are no more presents on the table, every player will count how many of their gifts match the ones represented in their Gift List. The player who came closest to fulfill their Gift List will be appointed the winner.

item.description:
There are two versions of this game:
Royal Cup Icebreaker (the regular version) & Royal Cup Firemaker (the adult, NSFW version)

This is a strategic game designed to help shy, reserved and otherwise introverted people break the metaphorical ice, come out of their shells, get out of their comfort zones and let loose. It is similar to King's Cup but IT ISN'T King's Cup (we cannot stress this enough).

The game works like this: players take turns picking cards and responding to the actions on the cards, you could pick cards like Licktator, Royal Interrogator, Queen of Hearts, Secrets and many more. The objective of the game is to play your friends, making them share as much as humanly possible about their deepest darkest secrets. Players continue picking cards and fulfilling its actions until either the chain of cards is broken--which results in that player being kicked out of the game--or a Licktator takes a player out, immediately ending their Licktatorship. The last player remaining in the game, wins.

The game is a lot of fun, has a lot of elements from traditional games such as spin the bottle, never have I ever, truth or dare and other games, and it has a lot of hilarious rules such as No Cursing, Hodor!, CPR, Eunuch, Premature Pants/Long Live the King and many more.

The game is available in four languages (English, German, Spanish and Persian).

—description from the designer

Capture all the excitement of Miraculous with the fun and fast-paces collectible card game Throwdown.

With everything you need to play included in this set, you become the character. Be the Miraculous Ladybug, Cat Noir, or Hawk Moth. Equip your character and disarm your opponent to gain the greatest advantage. Call upon help from Kwamis (Magical Companions) to either devastate or regenerate each other's decks. Surprise with your signature attack but beware of Hawk Moth's traps.

THROWDOWN! is a turn based card game that uses the Draw-Attack-Discard system or D.A.D.s. During the game you will have a character, a deck, and a discard pile. First you need at least 2 or more people to play and each person will need to have their own character card and deck. The objective of the game is to attack your opponents deck. You do this with your character card and cards you draw from your deck. You win when their deck is completely depleted. No matter how many people play you will always attack the person to your left, so until you get down to two players you cannot attack the person that attacked you.

Setting up to play is easy just place your character card next to your deck and your discard pile will go on the other side of your character. Flip a coin to see who goes first, then follow 3 easy steps.

STEP 1 DRAW - On your turn DRAW a card from your deck and place it in front of your character card. 
STEP 2 ATTACK - Your character must ATTACK on your turn and will automatically defend your deck on your opponents turn. Total and resolve conflict damage. Follow any additional rules on the card.
STEP 3 DISCARD - Now discard the card in play and put it into your discard pile, it is now your opponents turn and they follow the 3 easy steps.

item.description:
Play food and topping cards on your own plate or on your opponents' plates. Haggis? Here...you enjoy that. Form bonus-point combos to maximize your score. Ketchup on ice cream? Yep. Use over a dozen different action cards to feed the dog, steal a pile from another player's plate, initiate a food fight, and many more. Or use one of your turn's actions to draw a new card from the buffet. Great for strategy fans and point maximizers, yet accessible and quick enough for kids. And everybody enjoys the hilariously disgusting food combos that get created. Picky Eater is played over three meals (rounds), with each meal lasting until there's only one player remaining with any empty spots on their plate. Whoever has accumulated the most points at the end of the third meal wins!

—description from the publisher

You are a mapmaker, which means you make maps… and determine who wins elections.

You belong to a political party: Red Elephants, Blue Donkeys, Yellow Porcupines, or Green Leaves. Your only job? Make sure your party wins the next election. You get to redraw the districts. But so do the other mapmakers.

Everyone starts with the same number of voters, spread across counties. Players each place four district borders per turn. When a district gets closed off, whoever has the most voters inside claims it. At the end of the game, the entire board will be sectioned into districts. The party with the most districts wins. If there’s a tie, the party with the most swing counties wins.

You must scramble to draw the best lines first. Can you crack and pack voters? Can you scheme and strategize? Can you create unfair, lopsided, strangely shaped districts that will guarantee your party’s victory? Mapmaker: The Gerrymandering Game is fast to learn and fast to play. It’s full of surprises, maneuvers, and outmaneuvers. It’s a hands-on way to try out gerrymandering yourself.

-description from designer

item.description:
Mad Dog Cards is a fun, family friendly game for 2-6 players from age 7+. Mad Dog Cards was created to increase awareness of how many animals are sad, lonely, and even "mad", awaiting a forever home. A "Mad Dog" represents a homeless or shelter dog.
 Mad Dog Cards is a simple card game. The main objective is find a "Mad Dog" a home or owner. Players take turns drawing cards and completing up to 2 actions. If a "Mad Dog" card is drawn, player must find an owner. If the player can't find it a home or owner, that player loses. The winner is the last man standing. 
 Yellow personality cards are collected to swipe other players' cards or even retrieve cards from the discard deck. Action cards are used to stack the game in one's favor. One can choose to pick on a player and force their hand in playing a "Mad Dog." However, with a "Crazy Cat Lady" card, there is no telling how a setup will turn out!

Publisher Description

The Fast Fun Card game, designed by David Harmer (author of Aftermath! Technology!, Aftermath! Magic!, and Aftermath! Survival Guide). This single-deck card game is a quick to learn game for 2-6 players. Only 5 minutes to learn, but can be played for hours. Many of the cards change the game rules, but the details are printed on the card.

User Summary

This card game was sold online through the Fantasy Games Unlimited Website. The shrinkwrapped deck of cards had card backs marked "FH" and included the first expansion which adds new cards to the game.

name.value: Legends of Signum: Battle for Vallor

item.description:
It is a miniatures wargame and a collectible card game. Two players with the help of their heroes, characters and support cards fighting on the Battlefield. Also in the game presented economy system, before the battle you need to construct your own City(with help of building cards) and collect prosperity points, which helps to summon characters for battle, build terrains or ruins to disrupt opponent's plans and use different spells, tactics and relics to make your army completely great!

There are two possible win conditions in the game:
1) Warrior path: To defeat enemy Hero
2) Economy path: To accumulate necessary level of prosperity points(51)
Only you will choose your path, be warlike warrior or strategist, trying always to be one step ahead - all is up to you! 

Squads of creatures fight under the leadership of Heroes.

First Edition - "Legends of Signum: Battle for Vallor" will immerse you into a fantasy world. There are represented two factions, which are in confrontation to each other, the Holy Grypharim Empire - this huge Empire inhabited by angel-like creatures Grypharims, the combination of human and griffins makes them a really skillful and powerful warriors, on the other hand the Free City Vallor - trading city, where representatives of various peoples from every corner of Signum have blended like in a melting pot. Here are possible any alliances, even between the most implacable enemies. You can also find the third part of the confrontation - mercenaries, they are neutral, but avid for gold and glory, so they are ready to join everyone who will pay.

On our Kickstarter you will find all the necessary for the game:

1) Starter Box "the Free City of Vallor" and Starter Box "the Holy Grypharim Empire" where you will find One Hero(Brissa de Molforn for Vallor and Roland the Proud for Grypharims), characters and cards with corresponding faction, dice, tokens and markers.
2) Core Box with both factions in one box includes everything in both starter sets + Battlefield.
3) Advanced Core Box with everything in Core Box + Four additional Heroes, 11 mercenaries,
high quality Battlefield, high quality prosperity coins.
4) Add-ons where you can purchase additional Heroes, characters, some miniatures of terrains and buildings, boosters rulesbook and more.
5) All-inclusive set (now in development)with everything in our Advanced Core Box including Add-ons.

Thanks to a team of excellent artists and sculptors, every miniature in the game has an original look and its own character.

—description from the designer

A greasy spin on the classic game. Take turns moving around the Trailer Park buying businesses from Sunnyvale, bankrupt the other players, and avoid getting evicted to win!

Play as one of 6 unique tokens like Swayze train, shopping cart, dope trailer, and more. Features sheds & trailers and Way She Goes & Community Day cards

-description from publisher

Your mission? Lead a daring rescue attempt to save innocent citizens from the corrupted Paris Nouveau government. You've been in this together from the beginning. You've had each other's backs, but we fear some of your team may have been bought off by the hunters — especially since our last team didn't come back. Trust no one but yourself!

In Exodus: Paris Nouveau, you're a member of a specialist team sent on a rescue mission to save refugees trapped in an urban warzone. At the start of the game, the players are secretly and randomly divided into two teams: those with a secret hunter ID card are on the hunters team, and those with a secret rescuer ID card are on the rescuers team. The problem is that although you know which team you're on, you don't know which of the other players are also on your team and which are on the other team!

Further, in Exodus: Paris Nouveau, you win or lose as a team. Throughout the game, you use abilities, deduction, and guesswork to determine your team members, and together strive to win as a team. The game may end in a number of ways:


 If a player has no life tokens, the game immediately ends. That player reveals their secret ID card and their team loses, resulting in a win for the other team. 
 The hunters win (and the rescuers lose) immediately if no cover tokens remain in the game. 
 The hunters win (and the rescuers lose) immediately if the total hunter distance (i.e., the sum of the distance values on all face-up cards in the hunter line) equals or exceeds the total rescuer distance (i.e., the number of distance tokens remaining in the game plus the sum of the distance values on all face-up cards in the rescuer line).
 If the game hasn't ended beforehand, it concludes at the end of the seventh round. In this case, the rescuer's team score is the number of victory point icons on the face-up cards in the rescuer line (i.e., each running figure symbol is worth one victory point), and the hunter's team score is the number of victory point icons on the face-up cards in the hunter line. Whichever team has the higher score wins.
 If scores are tied, continue playing rounds until either an immediate-win condition has been met or at the end of a round one team has a higher score than the other, at which point they're declared the winning team.

item.description:
Lord of the Jungle is a cooperative game for 1 to 4 players that can be played in 60 to 90 minutes.

In this thematic adventure game, you play as Tarzan, Jane, and their allies. Lay out cards to create a map of Africa, and then fight your way across the map to reach the lost city of Opar! Each map card that you choose in your journey reveals your next encounter. Each encounter pits you against a specific tile layout, and an assortment of enemies and interactive 3D trees. Fight enemies by using your equipment cards and rolling dice.

Be careful to keep Tarzan and Jane out of danger. If either of them perish, the game is lost! If you're able to fight through the scenarios and make your way to Opar, all that's left in front of you is a final boss fight. Work together and take down the boss to win the game!

-description from designer

Zombie Apocalypse is a light roll-and-move game in which you must navigate through a building filled with zombies and escape to safety.

At the start of the game, a gun is randomly placed on the board via die roll and 6 zombies are placed in the indicated starting positions. You move by rolling a dice and moving that number of squares on the board - which can be diagonal or orthogonal movement. The zombies also move by die roll with each result indicating the direction they'll move.

If you're able to find the gun you can shoot the zombies, but otherwise you must just carefully avoid them and try to reach the bomb shelter on the far side of the board.

Shadowrun: Sprawl Ops is a competitive game for 2 to 4 players that can be played in 60 to 90 minutes. In this cyber-punk worker-placement game, each player controls a team of Shadow Runners that they can send on missions, loan to other players (for a fee, of course), and upgrade with new tech and equipment. Missions are resolved by rolling combinations of custom dice. A diverse team of Shadow Runners gives you access to more combinations of dice, and your upgrades add even more dice to your pool. Take on smaller missions to earn creds. Then, put those right back into more experienced runners, and better gear. Once you think you've got what it takes, send your runners out to attempt to collect one final score. If you fail, don't worry, your doc-wagon contracts will keep your runners in the game. The first player to successfully complete the final mission, and collect that last big score wins the game!

item.description:
In Halloween, each player is a monster trying to be the first to capture a human in the center of the board. The game uses a simple roll and move mechanic to advance along the track, but if you hit a space with a dot in it, you will have to draw a card - which could send you a certain number of spaces forward or backward.

Each card has instructions for each monster on it. You will just read the instruction relevant to you. If you run out of cards, shuffle the discard pile to form a new draw deck.

The first player to reach the center of the board is the winner!

ãƒãƒ™ãƒ«ã®å¡” is played with 10 tiles, 5 black and 5 red, each player having their color. At the beginning, the second player places the 10 tiles face down randomly in a square grid so as to form a continuous shape of their choice. The tiles are flipped and the game begins.

Taking turns, players take one of their tiles and place it on top of a neighboring tile/stack. The following restrictions apply:
- you can only take one tile, the topmost of a stack,
- you cannot split the tiles in two different groups in the grid,
- you cannot move a tile to an "empty space".
If you cannot make a legal move, you must pass until a legal move is available to you again. You cannot pass if a move is available.

The goal is to have your own tile at the top of the last pile remaining when the game ends.

In NLT (No Later Than), all players have three Blokus-like tridimensional pieces: a N, a L and a T. Each round, a card is drawn, indicating a top, a front and a side view, as well as two of the three pieces. The object of the game is to use the two pieces indicated in order to build a structure matching the three views. Whoever is the first to build the structure takes the card, which is worth one point.

The game ends as soon as a player has 4 points. They are declared the winner.

Narcos: The Board Game, which is based on the television series Narcos, puts players in the roles of the series' most powerful characters and factions as they rewrite the story behind the rise and fall of El Patrón. One person acts as El Patrón, managing a growing narcotics empire while trying to keep their location on the board a secret. The remaining players lead the Hunter factions: the DEA, Policía Nacional de Colombia, Cali Cartel, and the guerrilla extremist group. These seemingly disparate groups are united in their common interest to discover the hidden position of El Patrón, sharing information and discussing strategies. If the El Patrón player manages to complete their secret objectives without being captured by the Hunters, they win. However, if the Hunters are able to uncover El Patrón's location, they succeed in their mission and win.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
In AARU players take on the role of one of the great and powerful Egyptian deities trying to draw worthy souls to their particular celestial palace in the Field of Reeds. To gather souls the gods play a game called AARU. Souls are won by winning tricks.

The souls of the Pharaohs are the most sought after by the gods. To win a Pharaohs soul you must deduce the value of one hidden card you own! Every time a player plays a card that could have been the Pharaoh card the opponents shout AARU!

AARU is a trick-taking deduction game for 2 to 4 players aged 8+. Each game takes 15 to 30 minutes to play.

GAME OVERVIEW

A game of AARU is played over 3 rounds and points are scored by winning tricks and by deducing and playing your Pharaoh card at the right time! Points can be lost if a Pharaoh is played incorrectly.

At the start of each round the players are dealt a hand of cards. All players pick a Pharaoh for the opponent to their left and add it to the opponents hand facing away from them.

In turn, players play a card from their hands with the highest value of the leading type played winning unless a Power card has beaten it. The twist is that in AARU whenever a player could have played their Pharaoh card (the one that faces away from them) the other Players say AARU to them to indicate they missed the chance of playing their Pharaoh. This way they can eventually deduce when is the best time to play their Pharaoh card for bonus points!

Points are totaled for each of the three rounds with the winner being declared by having the most points at the end.

Stand by to board: Pick up all your cards quickly, beat your opponents, and build the totem.

C'era un Pirata is a game for brave pirates who are ready to fight to the last card! Only the quickest will win the booty.

Flip over the card and observe the animal, but pay attention because you will see many of them and you have to remember them all. Pay attention: a hippopotamus, a whale, and then?

In I'm So Hungry That..., your real objective is sweet candy. Collect as many as you can to defeat your opponents. Don't forget that some cards will make you sound like an animal, and this will complicate things a bit...

A brave Viking can't set sail without all their brothers on board.

In Watch Out for the Vikings, you need to be a keen observer, use crafty strategies, and try not to be fooled by those thick Viking beards. Quickly run through your cards and choose your crew.

Pay attention and concentrate!

You must be a keen observer to win Quick Fingers. Turn over your cards, and after making a quick calculation, decide what move to make, always trying to be faster and better than your opponent. Will you be the one to bring home the most booty? Pay attention to the challenges and never drop your guard in this game for clever, crafty crooks.

In Siege!, one player controls an army that is attacking a castle and trying to capture the other player's king. The other player is defending.

Pieces in the turn are placed upside-down to hide their values. Each player has 10 pieces ranging in value from 1 to 4. The king is placed on a marked square on the far side of the board. Each turn, the players choose one piece and move it one square orthogonally (there is no diagonal) movement in the game.

When a piece moves adjacent to an opponent piece, the values of both are revealed and the lower one is removed. There are also "trap" units which will automatically eliminate any unit they are adjacent to.

The game ends when the defending king is captured or when the the invaders run our of pieces.

Tactical trading and travel game for 2 to 6 people.

The players each receives a colored ship owner (character) and the appropriate charge! The locomotion occurs with a W6 in five trades.
The shipowner can buy ships in cash or on credit on his train, the ship arrives at the home port of the corresponding area.

There are various instructions on "telex" cards, which means: "travel" the voyages from port to port and "round trips" the voyages from the home port to a destination port and back to the home port.
Only fully loaded ships can travel, if they are not fully loaded, they will cost you a "mooring fee" every time the player rolls a dice!

If you have his charge (you get this in certain fields of the orbit!) Completely, then the color chips are turned with the closed side up.
The shipowner and all his loaded ships move forward after rolling the dice with the thrown number on all their ways.
Ships can be bought or sold in their home port, and the area of use can also be changed.

A charter ship and the possible meetings of the ships in the same fields bring some additional options in the game.
You agree on the end of the game at a certain time, who then has the highest total amount wins the game.

—user summary

Is a quite elaborate music quiz in which the 2 - 5 players on several colored tracks with their 1 - 3 figures draw and depending on the field and train different technical questions to the music must answer!
The questions are on 30 cards, they are all designed with pictures, you do not need to read aloud!
The rules are very detailed and written in five languages (German, French, English, Italian, Dutch)!

There are several game variants:

 the game with question cards and cassette
 the game without cassette:
 Variant 1: the player determines his number of dice himself
 Different conditions apply here, the rule contains examples.
 
 It is played without a game board, either with cassette and playing cards or just with the question cards




The game ends when you play with the board when a player has all of his pieces in the finish field!
In the other variants, the correct answers are rewarded with chips, whoever has the most chips in the end, wins or the one who can first drop his cards he has received!

—user summary

In India, you and an opponent are trying to retrieve a dagger and bring it to the Taj Mahal. You will move along a path using a Carrom style flipping mechanic to determine how far you can move.

Each turn, the players will flip a chip in a box that is filled with numbered squares. The chip must bounce off the far wall and (hopefully) land on one or more of the squares. Your opponent will then look and the squares covered and decide which value you will move. You may choose to move forward or backward on the path.

There is only one dagger in the game. To capture it, you must land on it by exact count. You may also steal it from your opponent if you land on his or her piece.

The path is marked with yellow squares which give special events and shortcuts along the path. The first player to carry the dagger and land by exact count on the Taj Mahal is the winner.

Kingdom is a solitaire game. The rightful king has been killed by a usurper. You are a farmboy who is determined to get revenge for your beloved king.

You must travel to several different areas of the kingdom and solve problems for the inhabitants there. By doing this, you can eventually raise a mercenary army to overthrow the usurper.

Typically, the game uses a pickup and deliver mechanic. You will identify what the inhabitants of a certain area of the Kingdom need, and then find and bring that item to them. (You need to remember what they need since there is no reminder when you leave their area.)

The game does not use typical movement rules. You are free to travel from anywhere in the kingdom to anywhere in the kingdom on your turn.

You win the game by raising the mercenary army and moving into the castle.

Wok Star is a cooperative real-time game in which players take on different roles to help grow a Chinese restaurant in a tycoon style game. The clientele of customers is represented by a deck of cards with various Chinese dishes on them. Customers are served one at a time while a 30-second sand timer is running.

Each order requires a combination of ingredients to make. The board is used for tracking the levels of ten prepared ingredients in the kitchen. To prepare more ingredients, players spend dice in different combinations. All players are in charge of different tasks and all must work simultaneously because the timer is running!

At the end of each round, players pool their money and invest in different options to grow their business: acquire new recipes, upgrade preparation cards, or send out coupons to get more customers. The players must have a certain level of profit by the last round to keep the restaurant open and win!

The third edition of Wok Star contains new gameplay wrinkles: You can re-roll dice by "washing dishes" and modify dice by using "hustle". Fortune cubes limit how often you can share dice, and you now have daily goals that you must reach each round or else you lose immediately.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Pokémon psychic guessing game, with psychic, ghost, poison, grass, and normal Pokémon. "Gotta scratch 'em all!"
In this scratch off game, two players scratch off a square in the pyramid, recealing Pokémon, Team Rocket, treasures, ... Depending on the revealed icon, players get to scratch off other sections of the card. However collects the most Pokémon (points) wins the game.

To get out of Baketage Museum (ãƒã‚±ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ¥ç¾Žè¡“é¤¨), you must first free the four ghosts that are guarding the exits — and to do that, you must find the paired objects where these ghosts have placed their spirit.

To set up the game, create the stage inside the game box, then place your phone in the stage once you've downloaded the app needed for the game. Place the cards in a circle around the stage, then place each of the playing figures on a separate card.

On a turn, you roll the die, then move your figure the indicated number of spaces in either direction. You then take the card you've landed on and any other card in the circle and you hold those cards near your face within view of the phone's camera. The app reads the image on the back of each card and transforms each half of your face in some way. Perhaps your left eye grows to an enormous balloon, while your right eye curls like a rainbow. If the cards don't transform your face in the same eye, you return them to their places in the circle, with everyone else remembering what they saw on your face. Perhaps they should tell a story about what the objects you saw in the museum and why they made you look that way.

If you don't make a match, you lose one of your life tokens, and if someone runs out of tokens, you lose the game. If you do find a match, then great! Remove those cards from play. You're one step closer to escaping the museum.

The app randomizes which cards have which effects each game.

Sail your rum from your huge galleon down shallow tidal Cornish waters using your small cramped RumRunner boat. You must make several trips back and forth to port, re-loading your limited RumRunner hand with the best combination of rum, crew and florin cards. Changing winds and tides affect which areas of the board are navigable and how far you can sail on each turn. The waters are also full of whirlpools that can twist your fortunes for good as well as ill. Other players can set the local seamonster upon you to cause trouble, or sail abreast to start a skirmish with their ferocious or charming crew and steal your profits. The player who successfully stows the most florins safely aboard their galleon (and has a decent crew to defend them) claims victory.

—description from the designer

Combat HQ is a set of World War Two miniatures wargame rules.
 The game features seven combat missions and a campaign system. Also included are started battlegroups for late war German, Commonwealth, Soviet and US forces.

GAME FACTS
Game Length: 2-3 hours.
Unit Scale: The Platoon is the basic unit in the game and is represented by a model vehicle, infantry or gun.
Ground Scale: 1” equals 50 yards.
Figure Scale: Plays equally well with 2mm, 6mm, 10mm, 15mm and 20mm figures. 28mm figures are possible, but a large table is required.
Bases: No bases are required for vehicles. If you have based vehicle models, just make all measurements to the vehicle chassis and ignore the bases.

In the world of The Armoury, you and your friends must work together and put on the Armour of God to stand against the attacks of the Tentacled Creature of Disparage, a devilish foe who seeks your demise!

As you and your team do various Bible challenges such as memorising scripture, reciting the 10 Commandments, finding Bible books and more, you will score Attack, Defence or Utility points to engage the Tentacled Creature of Disparage in battle. Help other players who are attacked by this evil creature and be awarded the Armour of God.

All Bible challenges are done through a player called the Game Master who customises the Attack, Defence and Utility challenges in order to maximise your Bible learning! Once you and your team have successfully defeated the devilish Tentacled Creature of Disparage you will be awarded real-life Quests by the Game Master to continue the epic adventure and Bible learning away from the table.

—description from the publisher

End the Outbreak is a 1-4 Player Table Top Board Game, Players are the Heroes on a mission to Quarantine a worldwide outbreak, along the way they must battle hoards of zombies, multiple mini-bosses and defeat the 3 main bosses guarding the components needed to quarantine the outbreak.

Using Perks to gain advantage over stronger enemy mini-bosses, players must make their way through the game collecting XP required to face the main bosses before they buy the ending and End the Outbreak.

A feature rich roll and play Zombie themed board game.

—description from the designer

Inside the Cup is a simulation of the sport of golf using PGA Tour players and courses.

The development of the game started as a spinoff of the old Avalon Hill Golf game and then blossomed into something all its own. The stats the PGA tour keeps are much more detailed than ever before allowing for players to really show their strengths and weaknesses on golfer cards. Golfers are rated for driving length and accuracy. The cards show the golfers’ ability to hit greens from all distances along with proximity to the hole. Scrambling shots from the sand or around the green are captured as well as putting ability for distance and keeping away from the 3 putt.

Courses are depicted in colorful segments showing the good and the bad places on each hole. As shots are hit they end up in quadrants on the course that show the next club that will need to be used. Stay in the fairway and your next shot should be easier and hold better on the green. Hitting out of the rough or worse can make the shot to the green harder and might not hold up like you like. You don’t want to be too far off the green as those areas could spell danger, while around the green shows safer chip shots or bunkers to hit out of. Some greens even have adjustments that make them easier to hole out or some are more likely to bring out a 3 putt.

Gamers can just let the golfers’ golf or you can have some strategic decisions to make. Should I hit a little less club onto this narrow fairway? Go for it on this par 5? Should I go pin hunting or just play it safe to the middle of the green? Should I putt aggressively or just lag it up there and get off this green?

There are even ways to quick play the game. You can go hole by hole or finish a round with one roll of the dice. ITCG is a fairly fast playing game that can allow a gamer to take his favorite golfers out on some of his favorite courses without leaving his own table.

Dungeon Slayer is a 1-4 player, fully cooperative, card game of dungeon crawling adventure. Each player will assume the role of an iconic hero, who, through the strategic use of an action deck unique to that hero, will delve into ancient ruins, hidden enemy strongholds, and sanctums of mystical power. There the heroes will face increasingly numerous and deadly enemies as they venture into ever more dangerous chambers in their quest to defeat a deadly foe, recover a long lost relic, or other bold deed.

Dungeon Slayer is unique from other dungeon crawlers in that it makes no use of miniatures or tiles, relying solely on the placement of hero and adversary cards to define the space of the passage or alcove in which combat occurs. This makes Dungeon Slayer easily portable and quick to set-up, while still preserving the feel of a heroic quest.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Who doesn’t love building blocks? In this cooperative game 2-5 players try to build four perfect towers.

Each tower has a different color and is built by playing cards of that color in the right order. The players start the round by choosing the build order. Then, the players try to add cards from their hands to the towers. If they can't, they have to discard a card. Based on the discards of the last player, new cards are divided over the players.

Play continues until the first player runs out of cards. The final score is based on the height of the created towers. While only limited communication is allowed, the players cooperate to get the highest score.

item.description:
Inkarumi ("Stone of the king") is a roll and write game in which the players aim to be the first to fill their entire pyramid of 21 fields. Six sixes are needed for the bottom row, five fives for the next, etc., with one one topping off the pyramid. 
On a turn, a player rolls six dice only once and can check off all fields that are supported by two fields in the row below. However, if they roll more of a number than the row supports, they cannot fill that row. When a player rolls the exact dice to finish their pyramid, they have to yell "Inkarumi". If another players yells first, they roll is forfeit. Anyone who calls out "Inkarumi" in error has to delete some previously filled fields. The first player to completely fill their pyramid is the winner.

In Chai, you will step into the shoes of a tea merchant, combining tea flavours to make a perfect blend. Specializing in either rooibos, green, oolong, black or white tea, you will buy and collect ingredients to fulfill your customers’ orders.

As a tea merchant, each turn you will do one of the following:

 Visit the Market – The player immediately receives a gold coin and selects a tea flavour tile (mint, jasmine, lemon, ginger, berries, and lavender), adding to their tea box. If the flavour tile is touching tiles of the same type these tiles are also taken. Payment (gold, silver, or a copper coin) is placed in the money pouch corresponding to the furthest-right column the tiles were in. Players cannot have more than 12 flavour tiles in their tea box at any time.
 Select Additives – Tea additive cards (milk, sugar, honey, vanilla, and chai spices) are also needed to complete most orders. A player may conduct two actions in the additive area: selecting all of the additive cards of one type (with new cards drawn after the first action), resetting the visible cards, or drawing a card from the additive deck. Players cannot have more than 6 additive cards in their tea box at any time.
 Reserve a Customer – A player may also reserve a customer card from the customer pool from the visible cards or draw deck. If drawing a visible card, a new card is immediately drawn faceup into the customer pool to replace the card taken. A player cannot have more than 3 unfulfilled customer cards at any time in their tea box. If a player has more than 3 cards, a card is discarded and placed faceup in the customer pool with a copper coin from the money pouch placed on top.




At the end of each turn, a player may complete a tea order from one customer card in their hand or visible in the customer pool. A base tea token, tea flavours and additives shown on the card are needed ingredients, and placed in an empty tea cup. The player flips over a tip and receives a coin bonus, moving the thermometer round tracker up one notch if all cups are filled.

The game ends when five rounds of cups have been fulfilled. When the final order is completed, other players complete their last turn so that each player has played the same number of turns.
To score, players add up their victory points from fulfilled customer orders, and add their leftover money to this total. In 3-5 player games, additional points are awarded to the player(s) who fulfilled the most orders and most diverse tea recipes. Award ties are friendly with each winner receiving 5 points.

The player with the most victory points (from customer orders, money, and awards) wins the game as best tea merchant! In the case of a tie, the person with the least number of fulfilled customer cards wins. If still tied, the person with the least amount of money wins. If that does not break a tie, the victory is shared.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
To win the game by leaving the planet with most points before the meteor hits the planet!

Each player gets 6 game cards and an action card, while the crystals are store in the tin

Depending on how many players are playing, 2-5 game cards will be dealt in the center

All players can choose to scavenge for materials or raid other player’s warehouse by showing their action card altogether
Players that are aiming for the same card during scavenging needs to battle each other to win the card
There are 3 mini games to choose for battle!

At the diplomacy phrase, players can trade/forge/assemble/mine

The game will end in 3 turns when 2 “Doomsday” card are dealt

Players that are able to build a spaceship can tally up the points and the most points wins!

Make allies or betray them! There could be 2 or more winners or no one wins!

—description from the publisher

Each player starts with 1pc 8 sided and 10 sided white dice
Vote for a player to go first and choose 1 of 2 actions

Re roll the Green or Red 10 sided dice, can re roll both
 Call out A, B, or C and reveal a game card from deck

When the game card is revealed, all players can solve the equation by arranging the dice to provide the missing variables!

Players who got the right equation wins the card, they are disqualified for that round if they got it wrong
1 card = 1 point, players with most card wins

Games end when no more cards can be drawn or players can set the match point!

—description from the publisher

Draw 4 characters and place on the side
 A starting player can choose 1 of 3 actions
 A. Redraw the 1 to 4 character cards
 B. Challenge a player to win their card by playing the mini games
 C. Flip a game card to start the fun!
 If there is a matching character between the character card and game card, players can yell the character names/species to win the card
 When 2 or more players yell the correct match at the same time, we can refer this as “collide”
 These players need to quickly yell “Oops!” and yell the matching names again
 The player who is left standing wins the card!
 Players that yells the wrong match will be disqualified for that round and if they are disqualified for 3 rounds in a roll, they lose 1 card

1 card = 1 point, most point wins the games when no more card can be drawn!

—description from the designer

Litteral translation of title: "From nothing to striped toothpaste".

The game starts at nothing, before light and dark, and ends with the invention of striped toothpaste. A pedagogical game about the meaning of life and the purpose of humankind.

Cards follow a sequence a'la dominoes. A turn consists of the player who has the next card in sequence on hand placing it on the table. This player then has the choice of playing an event card, making players switch cards in various ways.

The goal of the game is to lay out all the cards, depicting a sort of evolution. The winner being the player who places the "striped toothpaste" card. Box contains 76 cards.

Based on a popular Belgian TV-show (Kabouter Plop), Plop Het Kabouterbos is a game where players choose a character from the show and try to make a path from the forest to their homes. The first player to reach his home is the winner.

Each turn, players pick a card which can be:


 a piece of road (to complete the player's own path or to mess up the competitor's path)
 a shovel to remove a card from the board
 a picknick basket (pass one turn)
 a gnome cap (allows the player to move)


—user summary

Best of Bourse is a deck of cards designed primarily for playing games in the live roleplaying world of Empire by Profound Decisions. The deck comes with rules for four different games which are quick to learn and play: Bourse & Build; Bribe the Bourseholders; Great Work! and "Cartel". Each of the games involve using imperial resources (known as White Granite, Mithril, Weirwood and Ilium) acquired from The Bourse to build magnificent wonders of the world known as Great Works.

Bourse & Build is for 1-3 players and takes 5-10 minutes to play. In the game, players control four Bourseholders who compete with each other and two Masters of the Mint to collect imperial resources from the bourse in order to build great works. Whoever contributes the most resources to a great work is entitled to name it; whoever names the most great works wins the game.

Bribe the Bourseholders is for 2-4 players and takes 10-20 minutes to play. The game is played over four seasonal summits during which players use imperial resources to try to bribe members of The Bourse who vary in their influence. Whoever controls the most influence at the end of the game dominates The Bourse and wins.

Great Work! is for 2 players and takes 10-15 minutes to play. Players invest imperial resources to contribute to building four great works. The player whose investments pay off the most wins the game.

Cartel is for 2-4 players and takes 10-15 minutes to play. In the game, players are Merchant Princes seeking to dominate The Bourse by controlling Bourseholders to create a Cartel with a monopoly in one of the Imperial Resources. Players roll dice to represent buying resources from The Bourse and use these resources to bribe Bourseholders. Whoever gains control of a Cartel wins the game.

Supernatural fans test their knowledge of the TV Series with TRIVIAL PURSUIT: Supernatural. This quick-play Trivial Pursuit game can be played on-the-go with its portable wedge holder. The 600 questions range in difficulty levels, so even super fans will be challenged! Six trivia categories include: The Winchester Brothers, Angels and Demons, Locations, Spells, Objects, and Rituals, Creatures and Join the Hunt.

—description from the publisher

Our best selling game will delight you while increasing and reinforcing your knowledge of Jewish traditions. 55 illustrated cards decorated with colorful symbols of famous dishes, decorations, and objects from holidays, such as Hanukah, Shabbat and Purim. Take the Spot It! Shalom tin for fun wherever you go, or use as an educational tool to learn Jewish traditions. There is always one, and only one, matching symbol between any 2 cards.

—description from the publisher

You'd Rather What?! is a “would you rather?” style party game for 3-6 players. The active player gets 4 cards which they secretly rank 1-4 in order of preference. At the same time, the other players must guess how the active player will rank their cards. For each card matched, the player gets a point. At the end of one round, the player with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

Escape Tales: The Awakening is a card game based on the escape room concept, but you're not limited by time when it comes to finishing this adventure as the game is focused on the story and your exploration of it, while engaging the puzzles within and making choices that will immerse you deeply. As for the story, here's the set-up:

Players take on the role of Sam, whose daughter has been in a coma for over two months and whose doctors still cannot explain how this happened or what caused it. According to them, everything is fine with the girl; she's healthy and shouldn't be in this condition. Sam is desperate and looks for answers everywhere he can, which leads to a weird meeting with Mark.

Mark's son was once in a similar situation, and his father was able to help wake the boy up. He has given Sam a scary-looking book and said that inside this book he will find a ritual called "The Awakening". But Mark warned Sam that he needs to prepare himself mentally since this ritual will transfer him into another dimension, where he should be able to find his daughter and understand what is the cause of this state. If Sam's lucky enough, then he will be able to wake her up as well. Sam has held onto the book for more than a week. Finally, he's ready to go into the basement and perform a ritual. Are you ready, too?

Content warning: suicide

item.description:
Jetpack Joyride is a real-time competitive puzzle game adapted from the mobile game of the same name! Players need to fly their way through a lab using a stolen jetpack over a series of three rounds. During each round:

1) Players receive four new lab cards.
2) All players, in real-time and at the same time, grab tiles from the common pool and lay them to trace their way through their lab.
3) Points are scored through mission cards or by collecting coins!
4) The first player to reach the end of their lab triggers the end of the round.
5) Scores are totaled and written down for the round. 
6) Players, starting from the one with the lowest score, pick a permanent gadget out of a river of four.
7) A new round begins!

Whoever has the most points at the end of the third round wins!

—description from the publisher

item.description: Seekers of Astrod is a search-based game set in the future where all players or teams are looking for the planet that holds Astrod, an element that can power entire planets at once. The players need to travel between Labs and other points in space to collect clues/findings and narrow down to the correct planet. Movement and other special actions are powered by cards. By using strategy, observation, logic, and some luck of course, the right planet can be found, and the first player or team to do so wins. Each time the game is played, the players enter a parallel universe where the planet holding Astrod may be different.

Crime Chicky is at it again! With her evil minions and wicked stink bomb eggs, she is out to make life difficult for the residents of Center City! It is your job as heroes of the League of Champions to thwart her insidious plots, save innocent bystanders, and capture her and her minions. The greatest Champion will receive the Key to Center City and the accolades of its grateful citizens.

Aim of the Game!
To win, a player must gain the most Victory Points by capturing Crime Chicky and her minions, saving bystanders and foiling plots.

Needed to Play!
The 7 Crime Chicky Dice (4 Basic Blue Dice and 1 Yellow, 1 Red and 1 Black Die), 12 Power Tokens, 1 Center City board with a matching counter, player boards for each player to track victory points, 12 tracking counters.

Playing the Game!
Each round, every player, beginning with the Starting Player, will take turns rolling 4 or more dice. A player must always roll the 4 Basic Blue Dice during their turn but they may roll the additional colored dice if they choose to. A Player may choose the Yellow Die (5 dice in total). If they choose the Red Die they must also roll the Yellow Die (6 dice in total) and if they choose the Black die they must also roll the Yellow and Red Dice (7 dice in total). The Yellow, Red and Black dice can give a player extra bonus Victory Points but they may also cause Crime Chicky and her Evil Minions to do extra dastardly things.

The player rolls all of their chosen dice, setting aside any dice showing Crime Chicky, an Evil Minion or a Stink Bomb Egg. These dice may not be rerolled.

The remaining dice may be rolled up to 2 more times, again setting aside those showing Crime Chicky, a Minion or a Stink Egg.

Once the players have played eight rounds, the game is over.

Scoring! 
In a two player game:
The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Evil Minions receives 2 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie, no extra Victory Points are awarded.

The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Crime Chicky receives 4 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie, no extra Victory Points are awarded.

In a three or four player game:
The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Evil Minions receives 3 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. The player with the secondmost Victory Points for capturing Evil Minions receives 2 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie for the most or secondmost captures, the tying players receive all extra Victory Points (3 or 2 depending).

The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Crime Chicky receives 5 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. The player with the secondmost Victory Points for capturing Crime Chicky receives 3 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie for the most or secondmost captures, the tying players receive all extra Victory Points (5 or 3 depending).

In either case, the player with the most Innocent Bystander Victory Points (after totalling up all points) is the winner and receives the Key to the City. If there is a tie the player who has captured Crime Chicky the most times is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Blob Lobber is a fast-paced card game for 2 to 4 players in which players take turns flinging blob cards. If your card lands with a bomb showing, you claim all the enemy blobs beneath it...but if more blobs turn up, your opponents may be able to bomb more blobs than you! Grab your friends and lob some cards!

name.value: Party Fowl: The Game of Drunk Ducks

item.description:
Party Fowl: The Game of Drunk Ducks is a card-based, light strategy game with area control mechanics on a modular board. Players win by being the first duck to score 21 points, which they accomplish by playing cards that dominate specific topics of conversation, sabotage other players, and transform their characters into party legends and the coolest ducks on campus.

You play as students attending Duck University. It’s the week before finals, and you're fitting to get fowl! You’ll need to party carefully though; the social pecking order at Duck U is a real cluster-duck. Strategically move your duck around the house and start conversations that make you the life of the party. Just watch out for those basic hens and duck bois looking to sabotage your fun!

The zombie apocalypse is upon us! The infection is spreading, and you must stop it… unless, that is, your cynicism, darkness, denial, or overwhelming hunger for fresh brains has overshadowed your will to save humanity.
 Who can you trust in this game of deception and shifting allegiances? Even those who are silent may be lying to your face. You must summon all your intelligence and intuition to identify friend from foe and turn your enemies against each other to survive. You must fight for survival as you are plunged into the war between Zombies, Survivors, and Maniacs, taking on the roles of up to 14 unique characters with special abilities and innumerable combinations. Only your cunning and quick thinking can lead you to victory. 
 You’ve only got to make it through the night—do you have the brains to get the job done? 
 Midnight Zombie Sabotage is here.

—description from the back of the box

Midnight Zombie Sabotage is a hidden identity game that is played in a single round, consisting of three phases: NIGHT, DAWN, and DAY. During the DAY phase, players will divulge and decieve before voting to eliminate a player (or multiple players in a tie). 
 MZS supports 3 to 16 players, who will take on the roles of 14 unique characters. You must use your character specific abilities, deception, and collusion to identify the enemy and convince the rest of the party to eliminate the threat while avoiding becoming a target yourself.
 Party votes to eliminate 1 player. Eliminated player determines which team(s) win if their their victory condition is met.

Forgotten Floof is a competitive resource management and civilization building card game for 2-5 players.

Cast out by man in the wake of internet pug memes, nyan cats and doge, the once beloved (but now forgotten) guinea pigs of the world must look to build a new future for themselves.

Each player starts as leader of a faction of 30 outcast guinea pigs all looking for a home. Your aim is to end the game with the most sheltered guinea pigs, hence becoming the most prosperous tribe.

To build shelters, players require resources. At the start of each round a number of resources are played to the centre of the table. Players mark the ones they wish to claim using their 3 action tokens and subsequently compete over them using their guinea pigs. The strongest guinea pig takes the spoils whilst the others are sent to the graveyard.

Resources such as wood, rope, cloth and stone can be traded in to construct buildings.

Each type of building allows the player to provide shelter for a number of their guinea pigs. Additionally, hospitals allow you to revive those injured in battle, prisons can be used to capture enemy guinea pigs, mines generate free resources each round and temples award powerful miracle cards.

At the end of each round players will see a number of their homeless guinea pigs succumb to a terrible catastrophe such as a comet strike, or being eaten by a fat cat - only those safely sheltered inside a building are safe. Eventually when there are no more homeless guinea pigs the game is over and only the player with the most sheltered floof will be declared the winner.

—description from the publisher

From the introduction:

"FK&P is a set of straightforward wargaming rules that has been designed to give novices an entertaining introduction to the mid-17th Century whilst also providing grognard wargamers with a challenging evening’s play.

The rules address warfare in England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland during the period from 1639 to 1651 known as the Wars of the Three Kingdoms, or sometimes as the British or English Civil Wars.

A square grid has been used to promote speed of play. This also enables figures which have been based on different frontages, for use with a variety of rule systems, to be used together. The rules are simple enough that players who have not previously encountered them – including wargaming novices of any age – can be taught the basics in fteen minutes or so and then learn the rest “on the job”. "
